title: BAZ BAMIGBOYE: Keira Knightley is spooked by her mangled Mandarin
text:
Keira Knightley had to learn some Mandarin for her latest film, but it ended up being all Greek to her.

‘It did take some practising,’ the 34-year-old Oscar-nominated star told me.

She had to learn some phrases for her portrayal of Katharine Gun, the real-life Government Communications Headquarters (a British intelligence agency) translator, who, in 2003, turned whistleblower to expose lies about the build-up to the invasion of Iraq.

Keira Knightley portrays Katherine Gun, the real-life Government Communications Headquarters (a British intelligence agency) translator who exposed lies about the build-up to the invasion of Iraq

Production staff working on Official Secrets — which was being shown at the BFI London Film Festival last night, tonight and again on Sunday (it goes on general release next Friday) — sent her a recording of someone speaking the necessary phrases in Mandarin. ‘I was listening to it and listening to it, and I think everyone at work was getting really annoyed because I was listening to it what seemed like ten million times,’ Keira (above as Gun) told me. ‘I felt quite cocky about it — I thought I’d cracked it. But when I listened to myself saying it, I realised that there’s a tonal thing that we don’t have,’ she explained.

Gavin Hood, who directed the cracking film, which also stars Matt Smith and Ralph Fiennes, asked her to record it again.

Knightley and Gun attend the Official Secrets European Premiere as part of the BFI London Film Festival 2019

‘A lady came in and read it out, and I recorded it phonetically. I can’t say that I was a natural Mandarin speaker — well, I clearly wasn’t, was I?

‘They were getting really annoyed with me at work, and I just didn’t realise how difficult it was going to be,’ Keira added.

She needn’t have worried. Her post-production work has wiped away any blemishes, and it now sounds as though Keira was translating away in the ancient language as if to the Mandarin born!

Knightley (pictured left) had to learn Mandarin for her latest role in the film directed by Gavin Hood (pictured right). She said she felt ‘quite cocky' about learning the language and thought she had cracked it. But open listening back, she realised 'that there's a tonal thing that we [Brits] don't have'

Breaking news: Matt Smith stars as The Observer journalist Martin Bright, one of the journalists who broke the story, in the film which is due to be released on October 18

Demanding role: Keira portrays whistle-blower Katharine who leaked information to the press about an illegal NSA spy operation designed. She is captured filming scenes in West Yorkshire

Ship-shape for a West-end Pi!

The celebrated stage version of Life Of Pi, a five-star hit at the Crucible in Sheffield in the summer, will transfer to the West End next June.

Producer Simon Friend spent more than three years developing Lolita Chakrabarti’s lively adaptation of Yann Martel’s bestselling novel about a shipwrecked orphan who survives in the Pacific Ocean in a lifeboat with a hyena, orangutan, zebra and Bengal tiger as shipmates.

Ms Chakrabarti said the play is about a boy who loses his family and ‘has to make some very tough, awful choices’.

The Life of Pi is to be shown at London's West End next June for an initial 15-week run. The performances at Wyndham’s Theatre from June 22 will use the same awe-inspiring puppets which were used at the Crucible in Sheffield

It will begin performances at Wyndham’s Theatre from June 22 for an initial 15-week run.

At the Crucible, Tim Hatley’s designs on a thrust stage were fabulous. Fin Caldwell and Nick Barnes created the awe-inspiring puppets, and they will be enhancing these for the West End run.

It revolves around 'a boy who loses his family and ‘has to make some very tough, awful choices’ with mesmering props and floor projections of sea and light

The theatre production was adapted by Lolita Chakrabarti and directed by Max Webster for performances at Sheffield theatres this summer

Cameron Mackintosh, whose theatre group owns Wyndham’s, has given permission for Friend and director Max Webster to install a platform in the stalls to elevate the seats. Friend said a core component at Sheffield was the mesmerising floor projection of sea and light.

Hatley has recreated the ship-shaped set so the front stalls seats wrap around the hull.

There are also firm talks about Life Of Pi heading to Broadway in 2021.

Producer Simon Friend spent more than three years developing Lolita Chakrabarti’s lively adaptation of Yann Martel’s bestselling novel and the production sees the front stall seats wrap around the hull to fully immerse the audience

The Bengal tiger peers out of the boat to see a tortoise making its way towards him, in the exciting production. Puppeteers control the movements of an orangutan, zebra, hyena and interloping rat in this production
